class.name: Word.Index
class.description: Represents a single index. The Index object is a member of the Word.IndexCollection. The IndexCollection includes all the indexes in the document.

properties.name: context
properties.description: The request context associated with the object. This connects the add-in's process to the Office host application's process.

examples.description: Access the request context from an Index object to synchronize changes and load properties for a document index.

properties.name: filter
properties.description: Gets a value that represents how Microsoft Word classifies the first character of entries in the index. See IndexFilter for available values.

examples.description: Get the filter classification of the first index in the document and display it in the console

properties.name: headingSeparator
properties.description: Gets the text between alphabetical groups (entries that start with the same letter) in the index. Corresponds to the \h switch for an INDEX field.

examples.description: Get the current heading separator style used between alphabetical groups in the first index of the document and display it in the console.

properties.name: indexLanguage
properties.description: Gets a LanguageId value that represents the sorting language to use for the index.

examples.description: Get the sorting language of the first index in the document and display it in the console.

properties.name: numberOfColumns
properties.description: Gets the number of columns for each page of the index.

examples.description: Get the number of columns configured for the first index in the document and display it in the console.

properties.name: range
properties.description: Returns a Range object that represents the portion of the document that is contained within the index.

examples.description: Get the text content from the first index in the document and display it in the console.

properties.name: rightAlignPageNumbers
properties.description: Specifies if page numbers are aligned with the right margin in the index.

examples.description: Set the first index in the document to right-align its page numbers

properties.name: separateAccentedLetterHeadings
properties.description: Gets if the index contains separate headings for accented letters (for example, words that begin with "Ã€" are under one heading and words that begin with "A" are under another).

examples.description: Check if the first index in the document uses separate headings for accented letters and display the result in the console.

properties.name: sortBy
properties.description: Specifies the sorting criteria for the index.

examples.description: Set the index sorting criteria to sort by syllable instead of the default stroke order

properties.name: tabLeader
properties.description: Specifies the leader character between entries in the index and their associated page numbers.

examples.description: Set the index tab leader to dots so that page numbers in the index are connected to their entries with dotted lines
Check if the first index in the document is formatted as an indented index or a run-in index and display the result in the console.
Delete the first index from the document

methods.name: load
methods.description: Queues up a command to load the specified properties of the object. You must call context.sync() before reading the properties.

params.name: options
params.description: Provides options for which properties of the object to load.

params.name: propertyNames
params.description: A comma-delimited string or an array of strings that specify the properties to load.

params.name: propertyNamesAndPaths
params.description: `propertyNamesAndPaths.select` is a comma-delimited string that specifies the properties to load, and `propertyNamesAndPaths.expand` is a comma-delimited string that specifies the navigation properties to load.

examples.description: Load and display the heading type property of the first index in the document

methods.name: set
methods.description: Sets multiple properties of an object at the same time. You can pass either a plain object with the appropriate properties, or another API object of the same type.

params.name: properties
params.description: A JavaScript object with properties that are structured isomorphically to the properties of the object on which the method is called.

params.name: options
params.description: Provides an option to suppress errors if the properties object tries to set any read-only properties.

examples.description: Update an existing index in the document by setting multiple properties at once, including its heading and letter navigation settings

methods.name: toJSON
methods.description: Overrides the JavaScript toJSON() method in order to provide more useful output when an API object is passed to JSON.stringify(). (JSON.stringify, in turn, calls the toJSON method of the object that's passed to it.) Whereas the original Word.Index object is an API object, the toJSON method returns a plain JavaScript object (typed as Word.Interfaces.IndexData) that contains shallow copies of any loaded child properties from the original object.

examples.description: Serialize an index object to JSON format to log or store its properties outside of the Word context.

methods.name: track
methods.description: Track the object for automatic adjustment based on surrounding changes in the document. This call is a shorthand for context.trackedObjects.add(thisObject). If you're using this object across .sync calls and outside the sequential execution of a ".run" batch, and get an "InvalidObjectPath" error when setting a property or invoking a method on the object, you need to add the object to the tracked object collection when the object was first created. If this object is part of a collection, you should also track the parent collection.

examples.description: Track an index object across multiple sync calls to maintain its reference while modifying its properties and reading updated values from the document.

methods.name: untrack
methods.description: Release the memory associated with this object, if it has previously been tracked. This call is shorthand for context.trackedObjects.remove(thisObject). Having many tracked objects slows down the host application, so please remember to free any objects you add, once you're done using them. You'll need to call context.sync() before the memory release takes effect.

examples.description: Get the first index in the document, use it to perform operations, then untrack it to release memory
